overall_score_comment: Four points for rhyming 'me' with 'me' and somehow making millions doing it.
the_roast:
Let's address the elephant in the room, or should I say, the 'shape' in the song: Ed's opened with perhaps the most groundbreaking revelation since water was discovered to be wet — 'The club isn't the best place to find a lover, so the bar is where I go.' Ah yes, because the bar, famously located in a completely different dimension from the club, is where true romance blossoms between shots that make you 'talk slow.' That's not romance, Ed, that's a concussion.

The real crime here is the thesis statement repeated approximately 47 times: 'I'm in love with your body.' Not your mind, not your personality, not even your taste in Van Morrison — just your body. And in case we didn't get it the first dozen times, Ed helpfully reminds us with 'I'm in love with the shape of you,' because apparently body and shape are legally distinct concepts in Sheeran's world. The whole song reads like someone trying to hit a word count on an essay about objectification but making it catchy.

Then we get to the date, which sounds like it was planned by two broke college students who discovered a Golden Corral coupon: 'You and me are thrifty, so go all you can eat, fill up your bag and I fill up a plate.' Nothing says 'I'm in love with your body' quite like stealing breadsticks in a to-go bag. And they 'talk for hours and hours about the sweet and the sour' — which is either profound philosophical discourse or literally just discussing the sauces at the buffet. The magnetic poetry continues with 'we push and pull like a magnet do,' a simile so scientifically accurate it would make your middle school English teacher weep.

The bridge descends into what can only be described as a printer jam of the phrase 'come on, be my baby, come on' repeated sixteen times. SIXTEEN. At this point, Ed's not writing lyrics; he's casting a summoning spell. If you play this part backwards, it probably just says 'come on, be my baby, come on' but in a spooky voice.

cliche_counter.cliche: Love at first sight in a bar
cliche_counter.quip: Revolutionary. Next you'll tell me people also meet at coffee shops.
The world's least sexy way to say 'we spent the night together' — congrats on the laundry bill.
Someone should really check on Ed's cardiovascular health with all this falling.
Repeated so many times I'm worried this is less a love song and more a dance instruction manual.
Science class called; they want their third-grade metaphor back.
When you've run out of actual words but the song needs to be 4 minutes long for Spotify payouts.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Drinking faster and then we talk slow
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Romanticizing alcohol poisoning as a meet-cute strategy
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory attendance at a seminar on healthy relationship foundations

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Fill up your bag and I fill up a plate
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Theft from an all-you-can-eat buffet disguised as romance
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Banned from all Golden Corrals within a 50-mile radius

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: We push and pull like a magnet do
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Grammar murder ('magnet do') and physics oversimplification
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Retake 5th grade science and English simultaneously

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Come on, be my baby, come on (x16)
lyrical_crime_highlights.quip: Copy-paste abuse of the highest order
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Community service teaching songwriting workshops on the importance of lyrical variety

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Your love was handmade for somebody like me
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Implying love is an Etsy product with targeted demographics
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to explain the difference between destiny and narcissism

hidden_meanings: Clearly this song is a deep meditation on consumerism in modern relationships — the buffet metaphor represents how we fill our emotional voids with physical connection, and the repetitive 'oh-i-oh-i-oh' represents the hollow echo of capitalism. Or, hear me out, Ed just really liked saying 'body' and 'shape' and figured if he said it enough times, we'd all forget he's literally just singing about being horny at a bar.
final_verdict: This is what happens when someone writes a song about physical attraction but has to keep it PG-13 for radio play — it's the musical equivalent of describing a steamy scene using only euphemisms from a 1950s health textbook. Shakespeare wrote sonnets; Ed wrote 'I'm in love with your body' 24 times and called it poetry.
title: Shape of You
